awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multiscale Simulations of Chloride Transport Proteins by Combined Quantum and Classic Mechanical Approaches
awd_abstract_narration:
Hai Lin of the University of Colorado at Denver is supported by a CAREER award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to carry out multiscale simulations of chloride transport proteins by combined quantum and classical mechanical approaches. The Molecular and Cell Biology division also contributes to this award in a co-funding arrangement. The research focuses on understanding the gating, selectivity and permeation of the Cl- and Cl-/H+ exchangers. In particular, Lin and coworkers are investigating how quantum effects, such as charge transfer and tunneling, tune the mechanism and the underlying dynamics of ion translocation. In order to perform these calculations, they are further developing the open boundary QM/MM method. Unlike conventional QM/MM methods, the open boundary method permits the quantum and classical subsystems to exchange atoms and charges on the fly in dynamic simulations, making it very suitable for the study of ion transport.

The ClC chloride transport proteins have been found to be associated with a variety of critical physiological and cellular processes such as neuroexcitation, cell-volume regulation, organic solute transport and muscle contraction. Defects in these channels lead to a variety of hereditary diseases

por.por_cntn:
The project has led to novel highly accurate and highly efficient techniques for computer modeling and simulations. The so-called combined quantum-mechanical/molecular-mechanical (QM/MM) algorithms describe a small active site at the quantum level of theory and the larger surroundings at the classical (Newtonian) level of theory (Figure 1). The treatment integrates the high accuracy of quantum theory and the high efficiency of classical modeling, providing effective ways to simulate chemical processes in complex environments.

However, dividing the entire system into two (quantum and classical) subsystems leads to two prominent limits in conventional QM/MM. First, no partial charge transfer is allowed even though there should be, e.g. when the two subsystems are connected by polar or hydrogen bonds. Second, the boundary between the two subsystems are fixed even though regrouping the atoms is desired, e.g. after significant relocations of the atoms.

Our goal is novel QM/MM algorithms that overcome those two limits and seamlessly integrate the quantum and classical subsystems. We developed and refined the adaptive-partitioning scheme, which allows on-the-fly reclassification of atoms as quantum or classical, and the flexible-boundary scheme, which accounts for partial charge transfers between the quantum and classical subsystems. The new methods will benefit a broad range of research fields including chemistry, physics, biology, and engineering. For example, the adaptive scheme is very suitable for studying ion migration in battery, assisting the design of next generation power sources that is more efficient, more competent, and cleaner. 

 

The project has also led to deeper understanding of the operating mechanisms of ClC transport proteins, which are associated with many critical physiological and cellular processes such as neuroexcitation, cell-volume regulation, and muscle contraction. An interesting question is: How do quantum effects, such as charge delocalization, affect ion binding and translocation in the ClC protein? People often think ions as point charges. While this view may work well for monatomic cations (K+, Na+...), it can be a poor approximation for anions. The Cl– ion is highly polarizable by the surroundings because of its diffuse electron cloud due to the excess electron. The likelihood of smearing some of the electron density to the surroundings is also large.

Our group, including 4 undergraduate students, has tackled this problem. Our model calculations discovered significant charge delocalization for the Cl– ions (~20% of the excess charge smears out to the protein) and unearthed the major molecular orbital interactions responsible for the process. Energy analysis further provided a satisfactory account for the unique "broken helices" architecture (Figure 2) of the Cl– binding sites, where the anions are surrounded extensively by the protein backbone (in contrast, cations are normally coordinated by protein side chains). The striking findings send out a message that the quantum effects, which have been largely neglected or underexplored in the past, can be substantial for anions. The quantum effects should be considered when designing new drugs targeting anion channels and transporters.

Many latest methods and data from this project have been incorporated into the computational chemistry course at UC-Denver, keeping the curriculum up-to-date in the fast advancing disciplinary.
